channel.title: Is Time Travel ever going to be possible..? You decide
channel.description:
"There was a young lady of Wight Who traveled much faster than light She departed one day, In a relative way, And arrived on the previous night"
Stephen Hawking
" Time travel to the future or going back to the past. These ideas have been repeatedly used by authors of science fiction, but is time travel really limited to fantasy? By studying the laws of physics, we will see if it really is possible to travel in the fourth dimension we call time.
You are now reading the introduction to this blog, you have probably already read the welcoming quote by hawking and you will maybe read the rest of the articles on this site (at least I hope you do so). This morning, you woke up in a bed (probably yours) and unless you're planning on going camping, you will tomorrow too. You are therefore certain of two things, that your past is unchangeable and that you are living at the present moment, only the future is blurry. Of course, it is easy to predict what will happen in a near future but it is impossible to prove that your prediction is true. Human beings see time as a strait line with no extremities on which the present advances like a dot on the line. This dot always goes in the same direction at the same speed and never stops.
In everyday life, it is impossible to go back in time, even if you read this paragraph a second time or if you lied down in the same bed you woke up, the fact you repeat your past doesn't change the fact you already did it before. We are therefore prisoners of this fourth dimension. We may get the impression that time flows slower or faster than usual depending on what we're doing (like when we sleep for example), but it's only an impression and a second will always stay a second. Unlike the spacial dimensions in which we navigate freely, time stays uncontrollable and impossible to explore. But the thirst of men for the exploration of unknown worlds is sometimes so strong that they managed to do what they used to define as impossible. During the XVIIth century, the steam machine appears and increases the freedom of movement in spacial dimensions; in 1969, Neil Armstrong sets foot upon the Moon's surface. Will it be one day possible to travel as freely as we do in space than in time? And if it's the case, by which means? Until then, treasure your best memories, live a good present and I wish you a long and comfortable future."
Taken from http://time-travel.over-blog.com/
Now, In my opinion I think it will never be possible to stop the time and space continuum, and reverse it. But I want to see how other moparians feel about this subject.

item.title: Is Time Travel ever going to be possible..? You decide
item.dc:creator: @MrFun MrFun
item.description:
@MrFun wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:103, topic:511773”][quote author=MrFun link=topic=630018.msg4313577#msg4313577 date=1371099660]
My physics teacher showed a cool thing on the YouTubler website that should us about transferring particles to another location if they where bind together, which then showed us another vid on a guy that is doing this same idea right now, but would it be possible by using this same idea with time travel?
[/quote]
Quantum entanglement? That have nothing to do with time travel.[/quote]
Entangle a particle to the past/future with a particle now

item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

You can indeed ask the question is Time Travel actualy going to be possible but if you think about what time actualy is it is just a name given by human species and that so time travel is in theory possible because time is just an illusion of the human mind.

Time is not an illusion of the human mind. Time existed before the human mind. Time is real and is influenced by gravity and velocity. Before the big bang, there was no time.

item.title: Is Time Travel ever going to be possible..? You decide
item.dc:creator: @_Vengeance _Vengeance
item.description:
@_Vengeance wrote:

You’re travelling through time right now. If you mean will we travel backwards through time, who’s to say we’re even moving in a straight line? We could be jumping back and forth between all sorts of different points in time, however our conciousness only remembers what it has known up to this particular point in time. Plus, these conversations never go anywhere when you’re discussing them with people that haven’t studied physics to a certain degree

Read full topic
item.source: Is Time Travel ever going to be possible..? You decide

item.title: Is Time Travel ever going to be possible..? You decide
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

yes, I mean, I don't want to ban anyone but if you aren't interested in hearing both sides of the argument, you shouldn't be here, nomsaying

and I must apologise, my blood alcohol level is like 0.270, very high


Of course is would be silly to ban it, but we would never have two equal sides where the scientific consensus is overwhelming. This idea that we have to hear both sides of the debate is silly and is threatening to destroy the science education in many places. There is no other side in this matter, it is mostly the side of those who have opened a science book, and those who haven’t.
I also don't agree with being COMPLETELY open minded, I think if an argument can stand on its own 2 legs so to speak then it's a good idea, but maybe that's just one way to interpret the situation
Yes, when an idea have enough evidence backing it up we should accept it, and we do. Nothing is better than new discoveries.

Read full topic

This way of thinking is dangerous, this is how we have gotten an alternative movement which sell fake medicine A movement who make up their own ideas without doing real science themselves.

of course, I agree completely here, but I think if I agree then I (am, you supposedly) some part of a conspiracitory movement, it’s hard to know what to say

I also don’t agree with being COMPLETELY open minded, I think if an argument can stand on its own 2 legs so to speak then it’s a good idea, but maybe that’s just one way to interpret the situation

item.title: Is Time Travel ever going to be possible..? You decide
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

I’m not being elitist (My grade from high-school is pretty weak) and I admit my knowledge is pretty basic, I’m just pointing out that he provides no real arguments himself, just telling us that we aren’t “open-minded”. This way of thinking is dangerous, this is how we have gotten an alternative movement which sell fake medicine A movement who make up their own ideas without doing real science themselves.

Yes we should be open minded to new ideas, but we should also try our hardest to show that any new idea is wrong. I will recommend a video series about Geocentrism and why it is bollocks.

This is a perfect example on how to tear apart a theory. Providing examples where the theory doesn’t match the observations.

Yes, we don’t know what happens to the objects which is going beyond the event horizon, but what is the safest thing to assume? That it combines with the core and make the hole grow (Consistent with previous knowledge iirc), or that the matter goes into another dimension?

If the black hole have a lower mass gain than what it absorbs (Take into account the emission of X-ray), then you stand stronger in your claim that it is escapable. (I don’t know if such observation exist).

[quote=“Niall, post:81, topic:511773”]hahahahhaha

can some mod finally ask this person to leave this section, please? we need MODERATION, not some people who are happy to stand on the sidelines in such discussions[/quote]
The simplest thing would be to ban any discussion about subjects that are not disputed (Most of science at our level). If you’re not a well educated scientist in the field, you are probably not going to find any mistake that the massive amounts of professionals didn’t see.

Read full topic

item.title: Is Time Travel ever going to be possible..? You decide
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

Rodgerwilco:

John Mitchell and French scientist named Pierre-Simon Laplace in 1783 were the first to believe that gravity could affect light.

well, gravity does affect light, how do you think astronomers do gravitational-lensing?

“A gravitational lens refers to a distribution of matter (such as a cluster of galaxies) between a distant source (a background galaxy) and an observer, that is capable of bending (lensing) the light from the source, as it travels towards the observer. This effect is known as gravitational lensing and is one of the predictions of Albert Einstein’s general theory of relativity.”

en.wikipedia.org

Gravitational lens

A gravitational lens is a distribution of matter (such as a cluster of galaxies) between a distant light source and an observer, that is capable of bending the light from the source as the light travels towards the observer. This effect is known as gravitational lensing, and the amount of bending is one of the predictions of Albert Einstein's general theory of relativity. (Classical physics also predicts the bending of light, but only half that predicted by general relativity.) Orest Khvolson (19...

this is a well known phenomena that is true for everyone, myself as a humble photographer and to incredibly smart people, mathematicians astronomers and scientists who design astronomies to deal with such phenomena

the problem is rodgerwilko is you look at people like me and bowser (and I REALLY cannot speak for bowser) and you assume that we are elitist, that we have closed minds etc because we are “book-learned”, you are completely wrong on this matter regarding myself and you come off as extremely close-minded because of it

but as bowser points out, THE GENERAL THEORIES state that once “something” passes the event-horizon of a black hole, that object cannot “escape” (we REALLY cannot know what happens beyond a black hole, although theories exist as to what happens between passing an event horizon and entering the “singularity”), and I “believe” that true, but then again black holes emit HUGE x-ray frequencies, and it’s not strictly fair to say “nothing passes a black hole” because stuff does pass in a sense, we wouldn’t know if black holes existed but they DO bend light through the process of gravitational lensing, black holes absorb light but then they bend light from objects “behind” them, so we can “observe” black holes in the sense in that they emit a huge gravitational pull and therefore they bend the light that was emitted “behind” them, but black holes themselves are the SIMPLEST mathematical objects that one can define, if you have so much gravity and so little mass, you are a black hole, THAT IS IT, and this ties in with how mathematicians thought black holes were simply a “quirk of physics”, but then we ACTUALLY OBSERVED BLACK HOLES, this was A GAME CHANGER, and this happened in the 1930s I believe

but the point I’m trying to make is that you look at us as “book-learned” and you look at yourself as smug and superior (or at least that’s the image you try and portray), you won’t even entertain the notion that you are wrong in that sense, you can’t even say the reverse is true unless you come from a distorted view of what science actually is

Rodgerwilco:

Since we already theorized hows stars were developed you plug the two together, since gas can collapse in on itself.

the process of a stars life is quite well understood, I shall reply to this when I am sober, but we HAVE OBSERVED STARS COLLAPSING WITH REGULAR ASTRONOMIES on the ground, EVEN WITH YOUR BARE EYES YOU COULD OBSERVE STARS COLLAPSING

it’s not some god damn conspiracy invented by astronomers, ITS’ A REAL THING WHICH CAN BE OBSERVED

[hr]

TO EXPAND ON GRAVITATIONAL LENSING:

to myself as a humble photographer, light is EVERYTHING, without light we would have nothing

photographers use light in ways they don’t even realise, the light from our eyes, it seems like an “original source”, but that isn’t the case, the actual phenomenon of the situation is so much more amazing, the light from the sun (and other stars, moon etc,) pass through the earth’s atmosphere (which can affect the light we view, see: greenhouse gasses), this light then likely passes to what we are looking at, the light of what we are looking at then reflects into our eyes (which, just fyi, are a lens exactly like camera lense), the light from our eyes is then interpreted by our eyes, and hence we see images, cameras are no different, the principle of lenses is incredibly simple and is a mathematical principle, light as it “passes through” an object is “bent”, lenses invert the actual lens etc, the real big discovery is that light doesn’t need to “pass through physical things” such as glass, or liquid (see: our eyes), but light CAN pass through things like galaxies and be affected by things like gravity

but when people say that “nothing can pass the gravitational pull” of a galaxy, they mean it in the sense that, once something passes through the EVENT-HORIZON, WE DO NOT KNOW WHAT HAPPENS FROM OUR POINT OF VIEW

WE CAN ONLY GUESS

SCIENTISTS DO NOT SAY THINGS AS 100% FACT, SAYING SOMETHING AS “TRUTH” OR AS “100% CORRECT” IS WRONG IN SCIENCE

Read full topic
item.source: Is Time Travel ever going to be possible..? You decide

item.title: Is Time Travel ever going to be possible..? You decide
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

I would agree, disagree and then agree again that nothing can escape a black hole.

In theory, we are affected by all gravitational forces, so you cannot escape a black hole or anything. But this is just silly to think about it in this way.

Let say your are closer to the black hole, you’re heavily affected by the gravity, but you’re still able to get away from it since the force from your engines are stronger than the force from the black hole. But this isn’t what people think when the say you can’t escape a black hole.

If you go behind the event horizon (The point of no return), you’re stuck there.

Please come with some arguments for your opinion and not only bash me and Niall for not making up fairly tales about physics.

Read full topic
item.source: Is Time Travel ever going to be possible..? You decide

item.title: Is Time Travel ever going to be possible..? You decide
item.dc:creator: @Rodgerwilco Rodgerwilco
item.description:
@Rodgerwilco wrote:

[quote=“Niall, post:88, topic:511773”][quote author=Bowser jr link=topic=630018.msg4309403#msg4309403 date=1370486787]

Rodger: So you have no real criticism of the theory of black holes?

Specifically which part of the theory? It’s obvious… when you understand how gravity works you would know that gravity affects light in addition to matter. The first theory was that if a star was so big and had a giant ass amount of gravitational pull, light would not be able to escape. Since we already theorized hows stars were developed you plug the two together, since gas can collapse in on itself.

I am sure you two believe nothing can escape a black hole…

You have clearly not understood how a black hole works, and you’ve not understood gravity either. Gravity isn’t based on mass (That is a simplification), but energy. So it is not a problem to drag light into it.

[/quote][/quote]

John Mitchell and French scientist named Pierre-Simon Laplace in 1783 were the first to believe that gravity could affect light. I was elaborating. You two need to stop being so ignorant. When you look at a theory you look at how it was then to understand why people theorized that kinda shit. Then you can compare it to the knowledge of today and determine if it’s outdated. You sit here and you want to talk about theories… get out of your text books, stop believing everything you read and face it with an open mind.

Now again, is there anything specific you would like to touch up on when it comes to ‘black holes’. I am sure you two still are ignorant and believe nothing can escape a black hole.

Read full topic

Specifically which part of the theory? It’s obvious… when you understand how gravity works you would know that gravity affects light in addition to matter. The first theory was that if a star was so big and had a giant ass amount of gravitational pull, light would not be able to escape. Since we already theorized hows stars were developed you plug the two together, since gas can collapse in on itself.

I am sure you two believe nothing can escape a black hole…
[/quote]
You have clearly not understood how a black hole works, and you’ve not understood gravity either. Gravity isn’t based on mass (That is a simplification), but energy. So it is not a problem to drag light into it.[/quote]

@The_Un-Named wrote:

[quote=“Rodgerwilco, post:79, topic:511773”]Maybe you can read a book or a netflix show and learn how light travels. You will learn that it takes light thousands of years to reach us from another universe. What we see today is thousands of years behind. We truly have no loveing idea what is going on in terms of orbit, expansion, contraction. Only time will tell.

In response to your black hole equation bs… we all know you divide by 0. Have a good day sir.[/quote]

can some mod finally ask this person to leave this section, please? we need MODERATION, not some people who are happy to stand on the sidelines in such discussions

EDIT: as a serious discussion piece: all universes are expanding from each other, universes expanding from us is NOT a localised event

item.title: Is Time Travel ever going to be possible..? You decide
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

Rodgerwilco: Did the universe molest you as a kid? You seem a bit angry at it.

If you had read in a science book, you would know that the universe is expanding from every point of view in the universe. Both I and Niall are open minded, but we see the need to follow certain rules in science. Like nothing happens without a reason and conservation of energy (And the other conservation laws, as these make it easy to see if you did something terrible wrong)

I might show you some of the physics/maths behind stuff like orbits later, if Niall doesn’t beat me to it.
